editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: TRICKS OF YOUTH, OR, THE WALKS OF ISLINGTON AND HOGSDON, WITH The Humours of Woodstreet-Compter.
A Comedy, As it was pulickly Acted nineteen dayes together with Extraordinary Applause.

q.hi: Carpere vel noli nostra, vel ede tua,

div.p: London, Printed by Authority for the use of the Author. 166 â€¢

div.head: To the Succour and Security of all Civil Wit and Learning: The justly honored, ESQUIRE &c.

lg.l: THE time is come again, in which we may
Use Tricks of Youth, and safely see a Play;
Hear Tavern-Musick, and such harmless things
As neither wrongs Gods Precept, nor the Kings:
For all those Recreations are set sree
In sixty one, were damn'd in forty three,
By those Trienial Traytors, who agreed
To make the Publick Faith weigh down the Creed.
When Ten Commandements they did deface
And put a League and Cov'nant in the place.
When in contempt of Spiritual Affairs,
In one day they cry'd down Prelates and Players,
But now the times are well return'd that we
Under the Sacred Beams of Soveraignty,
May in our Comick Nombers sit and sing
Peace to the People, Honour to the King:
Which aptly doth administer Occasion
For me to represent this Dedication,
To your good hands, whose Patronage is fit
To Crown the Play, and add long life to Wit.
For let Mens Wit be nere so well exprest,
'Tis witty acceptation makes the Iest.
This Play consists of Humour, Tricks of Youth,
Done by known Persons, Fancy mixt with Truth.
Which is ambitious of no higher Fame
Or preservation, but your Noble Name,
That, singly can sufficiently prefer
This Poem, and
SUre such a Glory, so Serene, so Bright,
Started from Chaos when God cal'd for Light;
For like that glittering Birth of Beams, you do
Transluminate this Western world, from you
Our Saint, our Soul, our Soveraign, our King,
We live and grow, as the Sun broods the Spring,
Then (as in Loyalty oblig'd) 'tis fit
We render part of our small Stock, our Wit,
Which hath so long been crampt under their rage,
Who durst not see their actions on the Stage;
That numb'd with a stupidity, we fear
We shall assault the softnesse of your ear.
We have been so perplext with Gun and Drum,

l.hi: Look to your Hats and Clokes, the Red-coats come.

lg.l: D'amboys is routed, Hotspur quits the field,
Falstaff's out-filch'd, all in Confusion yield,
Even Auditor and Actor, what before
Did make the Red Bull laugh, now makes him roar.
We curse the Misery in which our Trade is,
And are imprison'd, but our large siz'd Ladies
(Thinking to 'scape them) are torn by the throats
And like Wine Porters put in Petty-coats)
Dragg'd to the Muse for Plotters; But Your Presence
Hath nullified their power, and given us Essence.
Till YOU came hither all was so forlorn,
We wisht we had been buried, or unborn;
All things were Retrograde, the Night and Day
Were shrinking to Prima Materia.
We liv'd in such a strange distorted Age,
Men durst not see their Figures on the Stage;
But furious as the deform'd Lady was,
Who for revenge broke her own Looking-glasse,
They crackt our Mirror, and now none but YOU
Dread Majesty, can mend, or make us new.

div.head: To his much deserving Friend Mr. Thomas Iordan, on his excellent Comedy, entituled, The Walks of Islington and Hogsdon, With the Humours of Woodstreet-Compter.

lg.l: HOw have I task'd my self that now must clear
A debt that's due almost this twenty year?
And, by your lÃ¡rge improvements since, do finde
You much before, and my self cast behinde,
In such a weak condition, who can
Expect full payment from a Bankerupt man?
Yet know no empty shaddows had the Art,
To catch my prayses, but your known desart;
Though love obligeth love, the nobler tye
Of worth by knowledge is more fast and high;
With Poetry you have Musick; and as soon
As you have made the Song, you set the Tune;
Where both in measure so exactly dance,
Numbers court Numbers, Ayrs do Words advance;
Had I but room, I could declare how clean
Your Fancy wrought, which did adorn your Scaene
In several Plots, and Plays, this here exprest,
Will speak the noble Linage of the rest.
These Walks 'twixt Iflington and Hogsdon will,
(Like those 'twixt Tempe and Parnassus Hill)
Show how the Muses in their sportfull rage,
Set all the Town a Walking to your Stage,
With so much Wit, and Art, and Iudgement lay'd,
That nineteen days together they were play'd.
Now by the bounty of the Press we be
Possess'd of that which we before did see,
Not pleasing onely nineteen times read o're,
But nineteen Ages, or till Time's no more.
THe Author (as late custome hath thought fit)
Makes me the Prologue to his wandring Wit;
The Gate into his Walks, through which you may
Behold a petty prospect of the Play;
A Play of Walks, or you may please to rank it,
With that which Ladies love, A running Banquet:
And, though the Scoene be Islington, we swear,
We will not blow ye up with Bottle Bear;
Cram ye with Cream and Fools, which sweetly please
Ladies of Fortune and young Prentices,
Who (when the Supervisors come to find 'um)
Quake like the Custard which they leave behind 'um.
Yet to exalt your spleen, he hath invented,
Persons that you'l all know when they'r presented;
Nay they shall know themselvs, and that is more,
It may be then you ever knew before.
We'l shew you things not taken out of Hist'ries,
A loyal Lover, and a grateful Mistriss,
A futile Frenchman (acted to the life)
A jealous husband and a jocund wife,
That kisseth, danceth, tipples like a Tench,
A Chamber-Gallant and a Kitchin-wench;
A jovial Cobler (or a Quibler rather)
A Catchpole that arrested his own father;
A crew of Ranters to the Gaole committed,
A dead man rais'd, a Usurer out-witted,
A Prison-Pimp discover'd and detected,
The Compter character'd, the Hole dissected.
Here my Commission ends, lest I betray
The Plot, and shew the Clock work of the Play:
Your liking will (like to the Suns bright rays)
Lighten the Gaole, and plant these Walks with Bays,
Where you will finde some Flowers as well as stalks,
Then lend's your hands, we'l lead you to the Walks,

div.head: The Walks of Islington and Hogsdon, &c.

sp.stage: Enter as at the Sarazens-head in Islington Iack Wildblood, Frank Rivers, and Stephen Flylove; to themâ–ª Tavern-Boyes.

sp.speaker: Wildblood.
sp.l: BOy, Drawer.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Drawer, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: By and by, anon, anon Sir.

sp.speaker: Wildbl.
sp.l: Why thou Parte-per-villain,
Drawer and Tapster,
Are you so taken up with your Holyday Ghests,
A Gentleman can have no attendance?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Attendance? Yes Sir, What Wine will it please you to drink?

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: That is, which of three sorts will ye drink, Sack, White, or Claret.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Nay (with your favour Sir) we have more variety then those.

sp.speaker: lylove.
sp.p: Well then Sir, without farther disputation, bring White Wine, and let it be right.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.l: I shall Sir.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Well Frank, and how doth thy little Mistris?

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: What little Mistris?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why she that is the rarest, the fairest that ever was Maid, Iack Trimwel the Chyrurgeons wife.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Mum, not a word, our plots are almost discovered, I have kept some villains company that have betray'd me to the jealous Coxcomb (her husband) she'l be here presently.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Who hast sent?

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: My old Mercury, Alexander Pimpwel.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Look, you can no sooner talk of Pimpwel,
But the Drawer comes; sirrah, have you any
Whores in the house?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.l: I cannot tell Sir, I'le ask the Fidlers.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Hark you sirrah, have you any females in the house?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Yes Sir, there's half a score in several rooms.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Why you rogue, do you doubt whether there be
Any whores in the house then?

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Why thou rebel to Chastity, dost thou conceive the stock of Females vertue is so extreamly wasted, that in so small a number as they are, the most part must be vitious?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I, I vow if there were but two there, though my Mother were one.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: And thy Aunt tother.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I mean so, the other should be one of my Aunts.
sp.stage: Enter Alexander Pimpwel and Mrs. Trimwel.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Little Betty, your humble servant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: But hark you Frank, what Gentlemen are these?

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Friends of mine, most dear and intimate, salute them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: Oh, y'are a pretty Gentleman to send for me into company.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Lady your humble servant.

sp.speaker: Flyl.
sp.l: Turn to me hony, and give me a kiss.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: Turn to you Sir, which part? my face is towards you already.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: By the Cherry-lip of Venus, you are wondrous witty, Lady.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: I am glad Sir you so apprehend it.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: 'Tis not my apprehension can mend it.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Is she not wondrous fair?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I dare not tell you,
For should I grow so passionate in praise
As her worth merits, I might justly fear
Your fondness of her would suspect my friendship;
For in this age Experience makes it common,
He needs must love that doth but praise a woman.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: You wrong my friendship to suppose I doubt you.
It were an injury to her and you;
The base suspect from neither is exempted,
To think that you should tempt, or she be tempted.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: You are full of Noble confidence, I think she
Loves you well.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Or she doth well dissemble,
But here's the wo, what bondage is he in,
That lives in love, when all his love is sin?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: Gentlemen, doth my coming cause this division among you?
Such seperation in so few a number hath been unusuall.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Your coming Lady rather makes an unitie,
Frank Rivers I'le begin a round to thy Mistris.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Let it come.

sp.speaker: Fly.

l.hi: I vow I'le pledg' â€¢ a brimmer:

sp.l: My Mistris hath a Rosie Cheek
her eye-brows they are Ietty,
Then drink off a brimmer
to he that dothâ€”
For tis a Health to Betty.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Mr. Flylove is your name I pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Yes, so they say Sir.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: There's a woman without would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Prethee what manner of piece is it?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: A good homely creature Sir, some servant I believe,
A Maid-servant I dare swear she is not,
For her nose and belly do almost meet.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: A strange creature, either she hath a very long nose, or a terrible great belly, and now I talk of a great belly, I pray Heaven it be not the Kitchin-wench I was dabling withall once, when drink and a foolish humor possest me (I heard she was with Child) if it be, I am undone for ever, stay I'le go out to her.

sp.speaker: Drowzy.
sp.l: No Sir, she'l come in to you.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Prethee honest Drowzy.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Honest Drowzy I, I was honest Drowzy before I knew you.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Nay but prethee Drowzy that was once honest,
Let me speak with thee in private.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: No Sir, you have spoken too much in private with me already, Ecc â€¢ signe, and Jle speak to you here Sir; for all your fine Lass there in the silk, I might have been as fine as she, and yaw had kept your word.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: How now Stephen, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.l: What's that to yaw sir,
Pray meddle with your own business.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p:
Prethee be gone
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
â–ª 'tis an honest Lass comes with an errand to me.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: An arrant, what arrant am I, I come to speak to you Sir, and to have satisfaction for the wrong you have done me, ye shall nere carry it to heaven nor to hell.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: What the Devil shall I do, Drawer?
Prethee what hast thou brought me here, a mad wench?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.l: What would you have sirrah?
sp.stage: Gives the Boy a box oth' eare.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: A pox o' your greasie fingers,
An you were not with Childâ€”
â€”â€”If she be mad, I pray Sir do you tame her.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: How now Stephen, what's the business?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: What care yaw sir, you may go to yawr Gentlewoman in the long locks again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: What is the woman mad?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Mad! no she's as wel in her wits as you are, though she is not so fine for sooth.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.l: Mrs. Trimwell, as I live your Husband's here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: Marry Heaven defend.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.l: He's coming up stayrs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: What will become on's.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p:
There's but one way, and thats this, here is a door goes down another pair of stayrs, whilst he comes up, do you
run down, you may easily escape unseen by the back-side of Islington. Let me alone here.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I, I, come let's go, I think the devil haunts us to day.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.l: Pray whither go yaw sir,
I ha' more to say to you then so.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Prethee honest Pimpwel keep this mad wench from me, and do you pay the reckning, you know our old rendezvouz.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.l: Well, well, let me alone.
sp.stage: Exeunt Wildblood Mrs. Trim. & Flylove, manent Pimpw. with Drowzy.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Keep me back! sirrah Ile set all my fingers in your eyes, if you keep me back, though your name be Pimpw. you shal not keep the door at this time.

sp.speaker: Trimw.
sp.p: How now what's the matter? vanished, ha all vanished, only one rogue and a dirty whore, what are you, what are you, pray turn about?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Dirty whore, you lye like a base rogue, I am as honest a woman as thy wife, what come you for?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: As honest as my wife, I, I, it may be so good Porpus, I speak not to you, pray Sir where is all your company gone, where's my wife.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.l: Your wife Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: My wife Sir, I my wife Sir.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Dost thou call me Porpus, you may be ashamed to liken a woman to a beast, I am as like a Christian as thou art, or any of thy kin, my father was as honest a man as any in Warwickshire, and his daughter shall not be made a fool yet as.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Wher's my wife? what secret holes have you?

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: What do you ask me for your wife Sir, I know her not, nor you?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Anon, anon Sir, by and by, did you call? how now what's become of the company was here, who payes the Reckoning?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Hey day, what have they left their Reckoning to pay, they were in mighty hast it seems?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Was the woman in the black Guown yawr woife Sir?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Yes, which way went they?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.l: Marry 3. Gentlemen carried her down them stayrs,
You were best make haste after 'um, or they'l
Make you a Coock old afore you come, and then
You'l lose the sport.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Ile follow presently, I guess where to find them.
If I cannot overtake them.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.l: By the masse Ile follow too, for my Gentleman.
Is amongst them; Ile teach him to turne
Up wenches bellies, and give them no sartifaction.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.l: Well you have your reckoning Drawer.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: To a farthing Sir, if you'l stay Sir, Ile give:
You one pinte, because you shall remember the
Sarazens head in Islington.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.l: I cannot stay now, I faith sirrah, but next time
I come this way.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Well Sir, you are welcome, by and by, I come,
I come.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: So, so, a bad shift's better then none; oh the rage his head is filld with for his wife, and the belly full of vexation she has to find Mr. Flylove. Pox of all fooles, I wonder what mad folly posses'd him to lye with this dirty, greasy kichen-wench, was his appetite so sharp set, that he must needs be lapping in the Dripping-pan? well, Ile follow them; I know their old haunt (the Kings-head at Hogsdown) Jealousie hath many eyes, I must prevent the searcher:
sp.l: If all my plots hit right,
Ile make the Cuckolds horns hang in his light.

sp.speaker: Mercu.
sp.l: My fair Splendora, though my fortunes are,
I Humble as he that ownes them; yet I can
Love thee with holy ardencie; devoutly
As zealous men in prayer do their Saints,
Or Votaries their Goddess.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: I know you want not wit to coyn a passion,
And pray (with all Mercurio) conceive,
I know how many symtoms of true love,
A Parasite (in service to his Mrs.)
Can use to gain his end; 'tis not a sigh,
Dissembled sorrow in a far straind tear,
The folded Arms; Encomiums compos'd,
With many interjections, nor the trick,
Of praising what she's pleased with, can move me
To the least faith, he whose slow tongue speaks least,
In Love or sorrow oftentimes means best.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: I am sorry you should think I doubt your knowledge
I know you have a soul as full of Raies,
As Delphean Phaebus in oraculous glory;
You have divinity enough to see,
The purest love from nicest flattery,
Or I should ne'r affect you, tis my thought,
That she whom flattery can purchase to me,
By one more subtil may be flattered fro me.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: You give a large account of your pure thoughts,
And I beleeve thee with such confidence,
As to not do't, were heresie; I here
Resign thee all the intrest I hold dear,
In this weak frame.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: That shall contain us both,
Our hearts shall be one individuall essence,
To which we'l frame like passions, like affections,
By this divinest Metomorphosis,
The Gods (well pleas'd) shall terminate our lives,
Both at one Expiration in good age,
Season'd and fit for glory, more Divine,
Where in one orbe our unity shall shine.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Who's here (undone) Mercurio and my daughter
Embracing? Changes Kisses? I shall part you.

sp.speaker: Splond.
sp.l: My Father.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Splendora, your Mother calls you.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: I am sorry Sir I have such faulty ears, as not
To hear till your love please to tell me,
I attend her.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Sir tis to you that I direct my speech.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: I shall attend Sir what your speech directs.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: To this intent I frame it, whats the cause
You make it all the business of your time
In visits to my house? though uninvited,
I do not say you'r an unwelcome guest,
But till I know the motive of your coming,
I shall be cautious in your entertainment.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Your words do bear a strange suspect in them,
And this to me, the Son of him that was
Once your best friend; whose love hath made you rich,
The manner's somewhat strange.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: I shall be plainer,
I disaffect your neerness with my daughter,
I have beheld loose kisses fond embraces,
Her sighes to eccho yours, such wantonness
As may not fit a pair of single creatures,
Much lesse you two, confidering the distance.
Sir to be brief, I do suspect you love her.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Oh nere suspect so Sir, you may be sure on't.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: Why this is honest truth, fine right down dealing.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: And she loves you.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: I hope she will in time Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Tis well Sir, lend me your eare.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: I fear this whispering portends no good,
Here's pen and paper, Ile appoint our meeting,
Though we shall misse that ceremonious way,
Of lovely parting we were wont to have,
Ile find occasion to deliver this.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Nay which is more, you are a riotous man.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: And let me tell you Sir, my Child and wealth,
Shall not be both expos'd to your profuseness
Therefore (by my admonishment) pray leave her.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Sir did you ever love?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: But did you e're affect a Virgin truly?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: As man can do.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: When.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: When time and love had made me capable
Of woman and her vertues.

l.hi: In the green long walk by Newington.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Was not her presence all your heaven on earth,
And then her absence brought such sickly thoughts,
No novelty could mitigate.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Very true.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.l: With that affection I esteem your daughter.
Just such a heaven her blest society,
And such a hell her absence, had we not
By some diviner inspiration,
A little prospect to eternity,
I should believe all joyes of soul were her:
The most indulgent Mothers never lov'd,
Their fair ligitimate Babes with such a fondness,
As I do your Splendora.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: You are very bountifull in your expression.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Too niggardly, her goodness merits more
Then I have worth to know, or tongue to utter;
I think her vertues all are infinite,
And not to be examin'd, I have searcht,
With most ingenious and industrious boldness,
To take the height of her perfection,
But forc'd with admiration to retire,
For still as I drew neer her soul flew higher.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: You have exprest her merit and your love,
And had you an estate equall to either,
With worldly providence and care to use it,
I should esteem your motion, as you are,
Your polyte phrases cannot work on me,
Nor shall they on my daughter, whose obedience
Must be conformable to my dispose.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: Did you call Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: No,
But since your diligence hath got such wings,
Stay and take leave of your kind visitant,
And be not tedious.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: I have some busines may concern your good,
Which you cannot conceive.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: I do believe you.
You see my dear Mercurio, how adverse
My Father is, time's short, read that, farewell,
We'l meet agen.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: This parting is my hell.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: Sir the French Knight is come,
Sir Reverenee Lamard.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Wait on him in.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I shall Sir.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: Oh, my torment!
sp.stage: Enter Sir Reverence and Wildfire his Page.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Noble Sir Reverence, your humble servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Tres humble Serviture Monsieur.
A vostre Serviture Madam.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Sir you too seldome grace us with your visits,
Although our country custome cannot yield,
That fair and ceremonious entertainment
You French men use; believe me you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Gramercie Monsieur de mon ceuir,
Vat you name de Madam your datera.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: We call her Sir Splendora.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Spent whora?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Splendora.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Split whore a.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: The name is some what hard Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Begar so it is, Split, Split, Split whore a.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Splen.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Splen.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Do.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Do.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: ra.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: ra.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Splendora.

sp.speaker: Sir. Rev.
sp.l: Splendora.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Right Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Madam Splendora, will you give Sir Reverence,
Leave to kisse beshide your sheeke.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: Let it be but of one side I beseech you Sir, I have lately been troubled with the Tooth-ake.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Ile leave you sir to opportunity.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Gramercie Monseir, vostre serviteur.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: At your backe Monseir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Allo allo.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I am gon Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Madam your fadra say to me he would have me take you for my wife, my Lady, my Madam, my Madam Lamard;

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: Did my father bid you put me in hope of these phantasticke titles?

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Fantasie, begar be brave title to be wife to Sir Reverence Lamard.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: To be your wife Sir Reverence?

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Awee, and Sir Reverence to be your husband.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: I thank you Sir.
I hope that uinon will happy prove;
Where Sir Reverence is the beginning of love,

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar dat was right, me love you out of all cry, You shall be a Lady, when we have marry, wee'l go to Parry, begar was de brave City of the World, me will have you dresse like de Frensh Madam, and ride in your Carrosh, begar dis English Dresse is noting; 'tis not a le mode France, den me vill shew you de brave Pallace of de King, you never see such state in your life, Oh brava; brava; and den.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: Pray stay there Sir.
I wonder that a Knight of your vast wealth,
In your owne Country could not find a faire one,
Worthy to meet your merrit; I may doubt
You are not what you would have me conceive,
Or my too credulous father is inform'd,
And did your judgment, sympathize with mine,
I would not wish you to adventure marriage,
With any Lady of another Nation,
There is a fitness to be found in love,
Which very far transcends wealth wit or beauty,
By him that keeps me for a better end,
I would not be your Mistris, could you give,
All Paris, for Joynture; The truth is I am engaged.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Begar den you shall be no Lady.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: I shall be contented with my fortune.
sp.stage: Enter to them Nice and Wildfire.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: How is't Sir Reverence, what is my daughter plyant,

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar your dauter say she will no have me, if I Shall give all Pary for a zhoynture.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: You must give Virgins license to be Nice,
Things easily purchased are not valuable,
Is it their own worth or their scarcity,
That sets so high a price on Jewells think you.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Begar your dauter be foolish to slight me,
She bid me love de frensh Lady, begar so me can.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: I hope she hath not angerd you Sir Reverence.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar is vill know me can have de brave Lady in France.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: I do not question't Sir, she is too peevish.

sp.speaker: Sir Re.
sp.l: Begar me have scorn a Countesse in France, and
Have had two three love letter from a Doushesse,
Since I came to Englant, your dauter no know
Vat I am, she be foole begarâ€”Vildfire.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Sir Re.
sp.l: Donne moy me manteau.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Awy Monsieur vostre service.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: I hope you will not leave us so Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Re.
sp.p: Begar me vill stay no longer your dauter a scorn my love.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Be not so discontented good Sir Rev. all shall be to your wish, I have prepar'd a course banquet for you Sir Rev.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: She scorn a my love.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: This fool it seems is noted to be rich,
What's that to me? In dignity a Knight,
A Knight Sir Reverence, then he is of France,
The onely man of fashion (from whose Countrey
All things are acceptable, no disease excepted)
Let him go seek a choise in his own Nation,
French feats grow stale, I'le have some newer fashion;
I'le learn to love for worth, not one whose flashes
Blaze much, and are at one time flame and ashes,
Give me a man whose love is built upon
Eternal vertue and perfection,
Who loves for mental worth; not outward show,
And such a one is my Mercurio.

sp.speaker: Trimw.
sp.l: Art sure thou sawst them go this way?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Sure, yes sure enough, I'm sure they cross'd this field, went o're that stile, and I am much deceived if I did not see Pimpwel peep out of yonder Tavern window.

sp.speaker: Trimw.
sp.l: That's the Kings-head I know't,
Oh for some queint disguise,
My jealousie hath yet no occular proof,
These two years have I wandred in this maze,
And still been blinded by her sublil sleights?
That Rivers is the man I most suspect,
And yet I dare not think he wrongs my bed,
The very thought bred in a jealous breast,
Is proof enough, and then were he defenc'd
With Devils I would end him;
Oh! we vain men covet most to see
What we would not, my eyes can take no rest;
How many Moonshine nights and Summer evenings,
In various shapes have I walkt out to find her,
But never could?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.l: Would I had never seen the face of Mr. Flylove.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Thou hast even got, thy belly full of mischief too,
But prethe do not cry out i'th fields, though I'm
A Surgeon, I shall make but a mad midwife,
Thou hadst better repare to the City, and quietly,
For a month hire the next Cage is to be let, you
May buy a bed in Smith-feild, they come to Town,
In Cart-loads.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.l: No Sir, I know you'l lend me a room for one month,
I'le enquier for your house when I come to London,
How farr do you live from Cuckolds haven.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: A pox on you for a whore, you have wit enough to jeer though you had not to keep your Maiden-head.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.l: I pray Sir, is it not your black bird that sings,
I cannot keep my wife at home, my wife at home.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Out you greazy kitchen whore.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Why thou foole, is not better to have such a Greazy peice as I am, then to have a curious fine wife, and cannot come neer her.

sp.speaker: Trimwel.
sp.l: The whore sayes true, how now who comes here,
Musitians very good, I have a plot,
Come into my head, which by these fidlers,
Meanes I'le put in practise, hark you,
Honest Fidlers (Musitians I should call you)
I am a little Musicall my self, Gentlemen
Whither Croud you so fast.

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.p: Sir we are sent for to play to Mr. Rivers at the Kings-head.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Frank Rivers.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: The same Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Who playes the Citterne.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: That do I Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Very good, I have a plot that shall get you double the mony you expect.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: How is that I pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Why look, Franke Rivers is my only Companion, I would now steale upon him in the middle of's mirth disguised like one of you, I have a false beard in my pocket, I'le carry the Base, counterfeit to be blind, and that boy shall lead me, and in the conclusion he shall pay you for the jest.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: With all our hearts Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Drouzy what will you do?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Ile even home to London, but if you see Mr. Flyloeve tell him I'le serve him such a trick as he saw in's life time, I'le warrant him.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Farewell good Drowzy. Come Gentlemen let's about this business; Aha wife, y faith I shall over-reach you now.

lg.head: Sings.
lg.l: I have been a Fidler these fifteen year,
And never was put in the Stocks before,
If an good fellow will give me some B â€¢ er,
I'le Fiddle and suddle, and ner'e give o're.

sp.stage: Enter Rivers, Wildblood, Flylove, Mrs. Bellaflora, and Mrs. Trimwell.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Fair Lady you are welcome, I should salute you by your name if I knew it.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: My name is Mary Fair-chaste.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Fair and chast too, impossible; it is a Paradox to me.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Is it such wonder to be fair and chaste Sir?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: No, no, 'tis no such wonder, A fair Cabinet should contain a fair Jewel; but since we have had poyson in guil bowls, killing Perfumes in rich Gloves, Heresie in religious exact habit, and Treason in the well-seeming gravity of State, we put small trust in form; but what do I trouble you with these things, let's drink, sing, dance, and be merry boyes;
sp.stage: We come to be merry, &c. Sings.
sp.l: Gentlemen, what shall we do for a noyse of Vagrants,
I have a dancing desire to exercise my heels.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I have sent for Musick, but we want a woman.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Its impossible; Drawer.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Did you call Sir?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Intreat your Mistris hither.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: I shal Sir, she prevents my service, she's here already.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: How doth my Madona? my Belladossa? my Ent. Mrs. Sommer sinner, the Conntesse of Hogsdowne.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: You give me many stiles Mr. Flylove.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I have come over as many more stiles to behold thee my Queen of the Kings-head. Hark you; what rate holds womens flesh? in breif hast thou ever a peice of Impenitence, that will be sociable, and will desire, only her pleasure for her paines, if she can dance well, wee'l bear with any imperfection else; thou shalt not lose all; wee'l seem to want the knowledg of thy over-reckoning, and pay thee. You know we are noe Cittizens, that (to ease our bodies and preserve our pockets) keep a due Accompt of every quart and paper, by unburtoning our doublets; or doubt our own memories by calling many reckonings at one sitting.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: You are very merry Mr. Flylove, but as I am a vertuous sinner, you could never have chose a time to have found me so unprovided in a whole summer, there is but one woman in the house, and she is with a French man, yet I believe his greatest business is over, if you will allow of his company you may have hers, nor will he be any interruption to you, for call what you will he'l pay freely, and be as merry as you will give him leave.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Have they paid all?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: They are now calling.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Prethe entice them in.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: No twill become you better, he may conceive I have some end of mine own in't; your way of invitation will intice him, the society of an English Gentleman, is his only ambition.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Very well; I'le invite him.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Whither go you Stephen?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Sir I'le take my leave of you.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: By no means Lady, I'le return presently, aside. Iack Wildblood prethee entertain this Lady in my absence, she's modest, & thou art civil; but if you make your seeming civility a bawd to abuse me, look to your self.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well, well, pray follow your humor; Lady you are not merry.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Is the Gentleman your friend gone?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Some private occasion, he'l be here suddenly.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: I cannot stay Sir.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.l: Mr. Rivers; what is Mr. Flylove gone?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: where's the Musick?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: I have been as far as Redcrosse-street for them, they were playing to a company of Cittizens at the Queens-head, but they told me they would make all the necessary expedition they could possible, and attend you in Hogsdon here at the Kings-head.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Nay, I'le say that for thee, thou art the happiest Purvey or for Wine, Wenches and Musick, that ever was assistant to the increase of sinners.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: Who should I meet withall coming from thence, through the Fortune-Playhouse yard, but old Iones the Cobl.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Thou shouldst have brought him hither.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: I thought you would have wish'd so, and I have brought him.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: A Cobler; what is he?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What is he? why the rarest humorist of a Cobler, that ever was translated into merry company, his wit is jeering, tart in all such jeasts, nor will he spare the proudest he in plush. And speaking in a most composed strain, with countnance grave, no man can take exceptions, but may suppose it ignorance, not wit; You cannot chuse but know him, that is he that owed fourty shillings to an Allderman, to pay 12. pence by the week, when he did exact Coblers law, and made his worshipful creditor give him two pots at every payment.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Yes, yes, I have heard of him.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Then now you shall see him, here comes the man in Person; welcome Mr. Iones.

sp.speaker: Iones.
sp.p: Thank you good Mr. Allexander, I'le make bold to salute these worthy Gentlemen, noble Mr. Wildblood, I take it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The very same Mr. Iones, and how did Mr. Alexander, and you meet.

sp.speaker: Iones.
sp.p:
Honest Mr. Pimpwell (here) was walking I believe
about his accasions, I saw 2. or 3. Gentlemen with him, and introth because I was in my workydaie Clothes, I was ashamed to speak with him, but I thank him good Gentleman, he call'd me to him, and told me I should see some worthy Gentlemen of my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Here Mr. Iones, I'le drink to you and to your wife, do you remember since you put her i'th cage?

sp.speaker: Iones.
sp.p: I pray Sir how long is't since we were merry at the Sargeons head in Islington, where we drank Sack so long till all our mony was gone, but introth I think I brought but a groat with me; we came off from the reckoning though prety handsomly, but good Gentleman you were forc'd to leave your silver Seal behinde, but I think you redeemed it again in a little while.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, there he hath met you Iack.
sp.stage: Enter Flylove, Sir' Reverence, Lamard, and Mrs. Light.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Gentlemen I presume to invite this worthy Gentleman and his Lady, I pray be courteous to them.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Noble Sir, a friend of yours can never come unwelcome where we are; my service Sir attends you.

sp.speaker: Sir Re.
sp.l: Monsieur your tres umble umble vassale.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Sir according to our downright English Complement you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: Awee Monsieur, begar me tanke you heartely dere be English Complement for you agen, vat velow's dat?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: A very honest man Sir, and Beadle of the parish.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: A beadle, begar he be no forboon company, my Madam can no endure a beadle.

sp.speaker: Iones.
sp.p: A lack good Gentlewoman; no Sir, I am no beadle I can assure you, though the Gentleman pleases to jeast.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.l: Begar you look as like a rogua as a beadle.

sp.speaker: Iones.
sp.p: A lack, I believe Monsieur you have heard the ill newes lately come forth you are so angry of the sudden.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.l: Begar me have hear no ill news.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: then I'le tell you Sir, the sad report goes that most of the English Gentlemen in France must return to England agen I am sorry for't.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: Begar vas nothing but lies; how now'vat is here, Fiddles? Madam sall we dance?
sp.stage: Enter Musitians, amongst them, Trimwel disguised like an old blind Fidler, and led in by a boy.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well done, you are honest Rascalls, every man take his stool, strike up couragiously, and be sure have a speciall care he that plays oth' base Violin sleep not, we are no colls you know, you must not slam us.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen shal we try our footing, here am I.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: And here am I.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: And if this Gentleman please, here I'le be.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Vould all mine heart Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: I cannot dance believe me Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Nor I, we'l onely practise.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Light.
sp.l: Excuse me Sir, indeed I cannot dance.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Excuse me Sir, indeed I cannot dance?
sp.p: You shall not dance excuse me then, that Country trip is old, we'l have some novelty.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Are you perfect in the tune I gave you last to practise?

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.l: Very perfect Sir.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Let me hear it.
sp.stage: They play the tune once over.

They dance the tune once over, then enter into a figure with, the beginning of the first strain, Pimpwel and the Mrs. betwixt every change two persons drink till it comes round, and Pimpw. discovers Trimw. in the Dance, and at the end of several Changes he declares his discovery.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: Mrs. Trimwel do you observe that old fellow that plays oth' Base.
sp.stage: first Change. Wildb. and his Mistris drink.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trimw.
sp.l: Well, what of that?

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.l: By my life 'tis your Husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: My Husband?

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.l: Take no notice.
sp.stage: They dance, at the end of the next Change Flyl. and his Mrs. drink.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Come t'other Change.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Lady my service to you.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Pray let it be your love Sir,
Twill make the Health much sweeter.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Thou mak'st me wonder.
sp.stage: At the end of the next Change Mrs. Trim. and Rivers drink.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: As I live 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: What? he that plays the Base?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Come to the next.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Here is strange humours in this Dance, how they drink and whisper, as if they had capering minds as well as bodies; Hey! how my wife trips it, when she comes home she was with one Aunt or other; She's no Tavern-dancing company, no, no; Oh my blest disguise.
sp.stage: This last Change Pimpw. and the Mistris drink.

sp.speaker: Pimw.
sp.p: Oh your Bulls-head, we'l take a course to order you, you blind puppy, because you wink you think no body can see you; Come the tother Change, and conclude.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar vas mose brave, my Lady dance allemode like our Frensh Madam.
sp.stage: They dance the last Change of all.

sp.speaker: Iones.
sp.p: Introth Mr. Flylove you dance very well, but that you straddle so much, but if you take it in time that may be altered; Oh Mr. Flylove you have a little gone awry, but mum for that.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Well said Mr. Iones, do you remember one night when you cast Anchor ith' kennel, and call'd to the Goldfinder for a Coach, who mounted you in his Chariot, and drew you to the River Acharon at the back-side of Islington.

sp.speaker: Iones.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Flylove you are an ingenious Gentleman, I have heard high commendations of you by a Neighbours daughter a friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Prethee who's that?

sp.speaker: Iones.
sp.p: 'Tis a very good natur'd Lass, if she knew you were here, she would have a quart of Wine at your service.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Do I know her?

sp.speaker: Iones.
sp.p: Do you know her? Do I know Ione my wife? Do not you know Alice Drowzy?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Pox on you hold your tongue, this dirty whore hants me in a thousand shapes, I must throw her out of my memory. Come Gentlemen shall we have another Dance?

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen t'other Dance.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: I come, me like de Dance better den Song.
sp.stage:
They all dance to a sprightly Ayr, but in the fourth
Change they all dance off from the Stage into the Tyringhouse, where they remain till the tune is plaid once over; then they dance all in again, and come to their severall Figures, and continue dancing the tune once more over; then they dance in and out again as before; At the last they Dance quite away from the house, leaving the Fidlers to play to the Monsieur, Mr. Jones, and themselvs; having played an unreasonable while, they desist, and the Monsieur speaks.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Hold, hold good Monsieur Minikin, for begar dey have dance avay wid my Ladee; Rogue, Drawer.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Anon, anon Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Fere be de Zhentlemen and de Ladee.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: They have taken Coach Sir, and are at London by this time.

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.l: How? how?

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Begar me never saw sush a frisk in my life;
Vas dis de skip de Angleteire?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: I was bid to deliver this Note to him that plays on the Base?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: To me? give me't.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Yes, they say your ill fidling made them all dance quite away, they would have staid longer else.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: The Devils have unridled me; what's here?

lg.l: The Woodcock when his head is hid,
Thinks his body is unspid;
Fool when thou comest next to find us,
Bring some better trick to blind us;
Pay the reckning, or you'l finde,
There's a worser plot behinde.

sp.speaker: Iones.
sp.l: What have you there Sir, a Bill of Exchange?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Pox on your Cobling jeasts, you quibling Coxcombe I am undone for ever.
sp.stage: Trimwell pulls off his grey beard.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Begar de Fidler be mad, he tear his hair off.

sp.speaker: Iones.
sp.l: Who's this? My old acquaintance Mr. Trimwel.

sp.speaker: Trimw.
sp.p: Hang up your old acquaintance, do not trouble me, who would have thought that through this disguise their careless eyes should thus discover me, but I'le follow them as close as Death doth sin.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Sir you must pay the Reckoning first.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Shall I.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Before you part, it is your device hath made us lose the best Guests that come to our house.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: How much is it?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: One pound thirteen and nine pence.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Here's the French Knight, one of their company that call'd it in, let him discharge it.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Disharge it, begar my Lady have left me noting to disharge, she got all my mony and my Wash.

sp.speaker: Iones.
sp.l: Gentlemen, I'le go pay my part at the bar.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Your part, what's that?

sp.speaker: Iones.
sp.p: A three-pence, a good three-pence, a Spanish 3. d. and so farewell to you both good Gent.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Well, there's your mony Drawer, I must confess I drank for't.

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.l: Who shall pay us Sir?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: The Devil pay't, shall I be made a But for every knave to shoot at.

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.p: Sir, you are the cause that we have not only lost this mony, but our credit with the Gentlemen, if we had known you had been a Trapan, you should ne'r have been admitted into our company; you had other pretences.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Well, since 'twas my plot, I am like to pay for't, there's a French crown among you, pray get you from me. Sir, you are a stranger, and therefore I have nothing more to say to you, but to desire your absence.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Mee bee glad mee come off so, farewel Monsieur Bo-peep.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: The just cause of my fears I now perceive,
As evident as day-light; in this Dance
There is compos'd all that her wanton heart
Can give, or he can covet, I must now
Turn all my love to loathing; Sweet Revenge
I am thy faithful Votary, I will still
Pursue their foot-steps, and with wary eyes,
Watch their Adulterous Conspiracies:
Now I have thought upon't, if they defend
Their persons from this plot I now intend,
I will disband my reason, and resign
My Intellectuals, or what else is mine:
Look to it Gallants, the next time you view me,
I'le make you curse the time that e're you knew me.

sp.speaker: Mercu.
sp.l: Time and our fitter opportunity,
The pleasant entertainment of our love
Hath almost wasted; 'tis an hour neer night,
And we can tread no farther then to'th place
Thy Father hath expell'd me, we must part,
But urg'd to't with much more unwillingness,
Then heat from life, when souls and bodies seperate.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: Thou shalt not leave me yet, I'le plant my love
Above my fear, it is a nobler passion.
Nor shall my fathers frown have more command
On my affection, then thy brow, made smooth
By thy own love, credit me gentle youth,
Thou hast next rule in this weak mansion
To him that built it.
sp.stage: Ent. Nice. Sir Rev. Trimwel and two Serjeants.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: That's he.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: We know him Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Perform your task then.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: I'le warrant you. [revenge.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Begar me have wash him hither, now me sall be

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Stay not for bayl, I'le double your reward.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: You are a kind Gentleman: Sir we arrest you by the name of Mercurio.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Arrest me Sir, who hath employ'd you for this Action? At whose suit is't?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: At the Suit of Mr. Nice, a very honest Gentleman I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You guess that by his bounty for your baseness: What is the sum?

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: Twenty pounds upon bond, if you have speciall Bayl, produce it presently, we cannot stay.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Why is your time so precious that is spent to ruine man-kind, be not pray so hasty, where is the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: He is not far Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: What is your wil with me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Longer time for payment of your debt.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: I may forbear no longer, Sir you know the mony hath been due these 14. weeks, it is in vain to think you can urge me to an agreement, but my present sum.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: But not, I intreat that mercy Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Fond Girl ask mercy for your disodedience, I have appear'd too temperate with you, and shown too much indulgence; 'tis your cause that makes him suffer.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: And 'tis his abuse
Will make me perish; Oh remember Sir
You had a wife, my Mother, whose dear dust
With low and humble reverence I kiss:
Had you been seiz'd between two Tygers thus,
Would't not have mov'd her, made her plyant knees
Grow toth' dull earth, till the deaf Creditor,
(By importunacy more then compunction)
Had seal'd a truce 'twixt him and's undone Debtor.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Your superstitious knees in vain are bent
For this bad cause, Laws Moral and Divine,
Have still provided that each man shall claim
What is his right, I but exact mine own.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: What can you call your own, that you may spare,
Whilst still the cryes of widdows, injur'd Orphans
Beat at the ears of pitty; had this man
Trap â€¢ in the snares of Canibals) his own
The fair inheritance his birthright claims,
(Heaven pardon them that have it) I believe
You need not rack his body for your owne.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Your zeal makes you forget your self.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: My sorrow is too bold indeed, to see
Such pregnant hopes thus blasted in the bloom
Of teeming growth, nipt in the springing bud
Of spreading youth; to see mans span contracted,
Sent to the grave e're yet he can conceive
The end of his Creation, 'cause his Chests
Want coyn, not to supply, but cram anothers:
Ioves great impression suffers this decay,
For want of Caesars Image stampt in Clay.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: I'le hear no more.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: A little pray Sir,
He that's so indigent to want the means
Of rendring your right, whilst he enjoys
His fair and open freedom; Can you believe,
That being close pent up with Iron barrs,
Stone walls and Jaylors hearts,
Where every cowardly Creditor treads down,
The o'rethrown Debtor with a doubled sum,
That stands bayl-proof; is that a time to satisfie,
Unless he had the Elixor to convert
The Iron grates to Gold, or (which is best)
To nothing.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Officers what stay you for?

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: Come will you go Sir.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: How diligent in cruelty you are:
Have you the heart to think this good old man
(That knows the scales unto Eternity
Are pitty, mercy, love (the best Religion)
Fear of oppression) will commit his youth
To your ungentle usage?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: Pray be not mov'd with us, your father may release him.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: Look Sir, the Officers grow merciful,
And seem to bear no part in his undoing;
Shall men that study nought but cruelty,
Out-doe you in an act of gentleness?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Officers, I'le leave him to your charge, take Bayle at your peril.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: Sir Reverence, will you be bayl for him, you are good for nothing else.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Begar me be no bayl.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: There's a day for thee when no bayl shalbe taken;
Shall I speak one word with your Prisoner?

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: Two if you please. [gate.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Hark you Mr. Tripes, I shal find you at the Compter

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: Without fail.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I have another mischievous imployment for you.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: We shall endeavour to perform it Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Oh Sir, I know you to be deserving men; there's money, enter an Action against Stephen Flylove at the suit of Alice Drowzy in an Action of assault and battery committed upon the belly of the said Alice last May, the Planets being Venus and Mars Rampant, and the Sign Virgo.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: I apprehend you Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Apprehend me Sir, for what? you are deceived, you must apprehend Mr. Flylove.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: I understand you Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Farewel my understanding Serjeant,

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Come we must part.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: I'l come and visit thee.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Thy sight in prison is my liberty.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Can you conceit why I have singled you thus from the company.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: No, pray instruct me Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: The instructions are too easie to be good, since you appear so innocently modest, I'le be your amorous School-master for once.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: You'l teach me no ill Doctrine.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: No, no, prethee observe me, be but capable, and I'le warrant thee an apt Scholler.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Well Sir, so far as I perceive it's good, I'le learn.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I'le shew you the Lovers Alphabet, be observant then, and be not squeamish, but do as I direct you; When a Gentleman and's Lady do meet, A. the first letter is A salutation.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: The word begins with S.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: No matter for the word, give me the sence, B. the next letter, lend me your fair hand.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Very good Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: 'Tis in a very good hand indeed; nay I'le shew you more tricks by and by, it is so very fair that I must kiss it, there's a letter gone that stands for C. I confess C. may stand for another business, and fitter for the letter, but a kiss shall serve at this time.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: On I pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Nay, I shall come on fast enough, I warrant you. D. shall joyn both our hands, now do we look as if we were wrestling, which of us both should give the first kiss.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: You make your own construction Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I, I, no matter, it's nere the worse for that.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Proceed Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Stay, stay, let's pause a little, you'l forget it agen else, E. is embrace me, there I have hit you to a letter.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: You come neer me now Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I shall come neerer yet, for F. I'le stroak your cheek.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: F. stands for flattery.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Not at this time fair one, if you will tye me punctually to a letter F. stands for Faith or Friendship.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: That is the truest use on't.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Well, it shall go so then. G. is a Gift.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: I'le wear it.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Let me see you.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: First make an end.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: H. stands for Hug me t' you.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: I have heard of a Wine call'd by that name Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Were it Nectar it could not be sweeter then this.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: It seems your favour and my embrace do want no acceptation.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I. stands for you, and K. standing for kiss, is I kiss you.
By the breath of Venus y'have a pleasant lip.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: I'm glad it pleaseth you; to the next letter.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: L. is another kiss, it stands for Love.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: L. may be lust, but it should be Love.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I, I, it may stand for both by fits. M. stands for Mary.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: So it may for Marry.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Remember R. stands for repent, but I am far enough off from that. N. is the next letter, N. stands for ne're be good, you shall learn O. Q. P. V. in private, that is the full prick or conclusion of the Lovers Alphabet.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Take heed, be not too hasty.
Some that would seem more nice then vertuous.
Who use a blush, or modest bashfulness,
To vail their knowledge of ill propositions,
(Such as I'm sure pou make, though y'have a trick
To smooth it o're with your methodick wantonness)
Would be asham'd to tell you your ill meaning,
But I will not.
L. in your Alphabet doth stand for Iust,
And be not fool'd with such a vanity,
To think because you are a handsome man,
Or I so easie won to your society,
That I will do an act may hold proportion
With any baseness; if you can love truly,
Without a glance to any vild respect,
Reveal it, I was never so ill bred
To give discourteous answers?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Love, and love truly, are not you married?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: I am not now Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: A widdow and so cautious, I'le try another way;
Have I taken up an Angle instead of a Bona Roba?
Yes I can love thee, and can love thee truly, and heartily,
I'le swear so if thou'lt have me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Let me but hear you Sir, I'le swear as much.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Wilt thou, faith stay a little.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What do you pause on't Sir?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: No, no, I'm ready enough to swear, I am loath to cast away too big an oath, and I'm afraid a smal one wil not suffice her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Come I'le propose the Oath.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: By those diviner powers that govern Contracts,
Swear to be true to me.

sp.speaker: Fly
sp.p: By all those sacred powers I kiss the book, & ever wil observe it, come shal we walk a side now: Kisses her. Whose here?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am glad you are prevented; How vainly men in their rash heat will swear to what they ne'r intend.
sp.stage: Enter Riv. Wild. and Mrs. Trimwel.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How now Stephen, what do you flye from your Colours?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: No Sir, I flye to my Colours, red and white, I'm a right English-man.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Where's Pimpwel gone?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I sent him for more Money.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But that Heaven ordained al things for a good end, a man might swear that Pimpwel was created for a Pimp: how cunningly he found her husband out, & how suddenly the rogue contriv'd that quick escape; I will have him put in the Almanack next to the Gunpowder-Treason.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Or Gowries Conspiracy; In what a stammering case now is my French-man; and now I think upon him, I have seen a face as right like that in Parris.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Faith so have I.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: Were you e'r in France Mr. Rivers?

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Yes Sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: I have had a brother there these 14. years, and have not heard from him.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: What part of France?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: Paris.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: What was his name?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: Brooks.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I never heard of him.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Hast thou brought the mony.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.l: Ther's. 5. l.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Go and bespeak supper at the Iohn of Ierusalem.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: I fear it's too late.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: What's a clock?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Past 9.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: No matter; Lady you shall not leave me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot stay, to morrow where you please I'le keep an hour with you.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: we'l drink a pint & talk on't

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: I'le tell you news, The French Knight's arrested at the suit of Mr. Bonaventure an English Merchant for 6000. pound, is gone to prison, no bayl will be taken.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I'm sorry for't; go, prethee make haste.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.l: I am gone.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: Gentlemen, my business is to one Mr. Elylove,
Can you direct me to him?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: What is your business Porter?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: I pray read that Letter Sir, I received it from a young Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Gentleman! I hope it is no news from Drowzy.
sp.p: To my friend Stephen Flylove; I'le try what your inside sayes; Ha, come with all speed, Gentlemen I have sad news for you, Mercurio is arrested.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Arrested!

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: What devil did the deed?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Nice the rich Merchant, 'tis but 20. l. [1000.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: But 20. l. alas poor Gentleman, he can as wel discharge

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: He hath writ to speak with me, he is not yet in prison.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: At the Harrow-Tavern in Little Woodstreet.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Come we'l all go, perhaps they'l take our Bayl.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: No hang them, these Citizens will take none but Free men; We'l make a tryal though.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I would Pimywel were here agen, I am sorry you appointed a Supper.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: No matter, we shall know some end on't suddenly.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Let us defer no time, at the Harrow-Tavern say you.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Sir I must take my leave of you at next turning.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Well, meet me at the Ierusalem-Tavern, but be sure you fail not.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Your injunction shall be observed.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I'le leave a Glove at bar.

sp.stage: Enter Mr. Hemlock, Mrs. Hemlock, Trimwel, Mace & Tripes.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Mrs. Hemlock if you and your husband do not assist me in this plot of dexterious mischief (finister I should call it) I shal be disgraced beyond remedy; I have now met with an opportunity so pleasing, so fit, so apt to entertain my purpose, an hour where only Saturn is predominant, shall so jerk my light-heel'd Gallants, and the politick little Gypsie my wife, Flylove is the pin that must set all the other wheels a going, which pin this honest blade my old acquaintance Tripes shal turn, Mr. Mace I know your part is not the least in this revengeful conspiracy, be sure you use him roughly that it may cause a quarrel, and young Rivers will take fire at the least spark.

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p:
If scurvy usage will make them quarrel they shal not want it, I hope Tripes is not to learn to use a man scurvily,
I'm sure I have practiz'd these 20. years, and there's never a one that ever I arrested yet can give me a good word; The Players brought me oth' Stage once I thank them in a Play call'd the Roaring Girle, or The Catchpole, he was a pretty fellow that acted me, but he came short of the rogueries I have done.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hem.
sp.l: You have sent a Porter.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I saw him deliver the Letter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hem.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, 'cause this is a large room, you shall retire into a less, I'le shew them up stayrs, and pretend that Mercurio and the Serjeants are gone into the City to see some friend of his for bayl, and will be here presently, which to countenance you shall leave your pint pot half full of wine, your empty foul pipes and the candle, and when I shall give the watch-word you may enter.

sp.speaker: Trimwel.
sp.p: And now you talk of the watch-word, is the Watch set at Cripplegate?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hem.
sp.l: And hath been this half hour.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: If there be but the least disturbance, let your boy be ready to call the Watch up; can he frame a lye handsomly before the Justice next morning, I know the Watch will do their parts, only they have one fault, which is to charge every offender with one way of assault, that must be avoided.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hem.
sp.l: I warrant you for the boy Ned.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Anon, anon Sir, Did you call Mr.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hem.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Is thy name Villanous?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No Sir, 'tis a nick name my Mr. hath given me.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: But thou must now deserve it, can you if need be, abuse, I mean accuse a Gentleman before a Justice of peace, to do a courtesie for a friend of your Masters?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Of what degree must the fault be?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Of what degree? a learned boy, oh my dainty pickpocket, he hath faults at's fingers ends, the devil hath given us such equal gifts; let me hear your degrees my fine villain.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Time runs away, let me hear som of them presently.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why sir; I can accuse him for picking of your kocket calling you son of a whore Rogue, Knave, Cheat, striking of you with a sword, with a staff, with a pot, a Candlestick, or stab'd you with a Tobacco-pipe, orâ€”are you married?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Then if you will Sir, I'le swear I saw him lye with your wife.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: No, no, hang you, I'le have thee swear to nothing that appears like truth, you shall find cause enough to swear I'le warrant you, and so we shall have all.

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p: I should know this boy, a pretty ingenious Lad; Dost thou not know me Iack?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: My name's Richard Philpot, I was born in Turnbal-street

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.l: 'Tis true, 'tis true, dost not know me Dick Filpot?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No truly Sir.

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.l: How doth thy father, is thy mother living still?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No Sir, she's dead; did you know her Sir?

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p: Did I know her, I a dozen years before I knew thee, why thou art now, let me see, 1641. thou art now some 14. years of age Dick.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I am almost 15. Sir.

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.l: I think thou wantst half a year on't.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No Sir, I want but a quarter.

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p: I, thereabouts, didst never hear thy father speak of me Dick.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No indeed Sir.

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.l: I am thy Godfather.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p: Am I quotha, who would have thought to have seen this boy here; do thy duty; I shal find somthing for thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Pray Godfather give me your blessing.

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p: Good boy, thou art no Brownist, I see thou canst kneel to thy Godfather for a gift, so can som of them too for thy hopes, but y faith boy I cannot part with mony at this time, thou shalt have my blessing.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A pox of your blessing, I thought how wel you were my Godfather; had it not been for the hopes of your mony I'de have seen you hang'd e'r l'de have beleeved you, I know where my Godfathers are, though I'de have satisfied your humor for your mony.
sp.l: Boy, Drawer, Drawer.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Boy look to your charge, they are come.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: By and by, anon, anon Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hem.
sp.l: Go all of you into that room.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hem.
sp.p: The watch-words shall be, I wonder he stayes so long. Mr. Trim. I would not have you seen.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: No, I'le warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hem.
sp.l: You are very welcom Gent.
sp.stage: Ent. Wild. Fly. Riv. & Mrs. Trim.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Are you the Master of the house?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hem.
sp.l: Yes Sir, for want of a better.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: It may be so; what shall I call your name?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hem.
sp.l: My name is Hemlock Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Thou art half hang'd, thou hast an ill name Hemlock and a Vintner, bless me from thy wine; did there not a couple of Serjeants bring in a Gentleman even now?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.l: Yes Sir, are you the Gentleman he sent for?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: He and the Serjeants are gone into Cheapside to a friend of his that he hopes will bayl him, they'l be here presently, this is his room.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Why would not that friend come hither?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.l: He was in bed Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: A poor excuse, that man will scarce be bayl, that will not leave his bed to save his friend.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.p: I hope Sir you will do him some good, he's a pretty Gentleman, 'tis pitty he should suffer.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: It is indeed, hath he paid the reckning.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: How long hath he been gone?

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Half an hour Sir, I wonder he stays so long.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: How now, who are these?

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.l: Is your name Mr. Flylove?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.l: I arrest you at the suit of Alice Drowzy.
sp.stage: Riv. draws, offers to run at the Serj. and the Mr. oth' house coming between, he is hurt ith' arm, then coms in the mistris.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Arrest my friend!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Then let me suffer too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Murder, murder, murder, go run and call the Watch, my husband's kill'd.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: Beat down their weapons, I charge you in the Kings name to keep his peace.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: The Kings peace we will keep.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Or we shall force you.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Did nothing urge me to't but your force, I should not fear to break it.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Sir you have kill'd the Master of the house.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: I'm very sorry for't Sir.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: That is no satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: He is a man I meant no hurt to; Sir do you send for Chyrurgeon to night, I'le send you one to morrow, I guess the danger of the wound; Come Sir, where will you conduct us?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: To the next prison.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Oh that's the Compter.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Come then we'l altogether and make a merry night, no question but we shall come off to morrow; I pray Mr. Constable will you come for us betimes.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You shall have all the favour I can do you, I am sorry for this chance.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Faith so am I.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: And I am sorry too but cannot cry,
Now Is my plot made perfect, all the wheels
Are in a general motion, I must follow, I shall
Never think they are in prison, till I see them
Within the Compter-gates.
My singing Gallants your mad misdemeanor,
Shall bring you now to sing the Compter tenor.

sp.stage: Enter as in the Compter Wildblood, Rivers, Flylove, Mrs. Trimwel and Keeper.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Blood of the Rivers, thou beginst to droop,
Thy soul seems not so active as it was:
Where be those capering pieces of pure flash,
That made the genius of the place grow Comick?
By the wanton memory of Chaucer I could turn Poet,
And write in as Heathen English; and as bawdy;
I'le not to bed to night.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Nor I by Iove.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: By Iupiter nor I, shall we be jovial; why should we not; conceive this place a Tavern, one place may serve for two uses; some conceive it the habitation of the sorrowful, and our free spirits shall convert it to a Paradise of delight; Pray Sir what hour of the night is't.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: Past twelve Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: It is an age to morning: Frank Rivers, prethee cheer up the woman, she droops.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Dost thou want rest?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: Yes Sir, far more then sleep.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Thy mind's disquiet then, prethee be cheerful,
Sorrows are momentary as well as joyes;
Were lith' bottome of the Ocean,
I'd bear my head up, till my own weight sunk me.
Sir, can we have some Wine.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I'le ring the Bell for you, they are up at the Feathers-Tavern; they lye at a safe Guard, they'l have their money before-hand.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: With all my heart, we shall not be mis-reckoned then, here's money for a pottle of Canary, the night is somewhat cold, and Sack is sprightly.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Hugh, Hugh.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: What a Hugh and cry you make, I have stayed up these two nights, you are all mad I think, will you not go to bed to night.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Prethee honest Hugh (if thy name be so) fill us one pottle of Canary, let's have clean pipes and Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: Where's your money?

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: At hand, at hand, my midnight Drawer.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: Who's that, Mr. Rivers?

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: I, dost know me?

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: Do! Sir, I fill'd you many a gallon of Wine at the Bear upon Fleet-bridge.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Oh, th'art an honest blade, I know thee, prethee fill me good Wine.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: The best in the Sellar.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Hark you sir, is there not a French knight in the hous?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: His name is Sir Reverence Lamard, he lies two stories higher to the street.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: A lamentable story! can you not invite him down?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: I'le try Sir.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Th'art an honest Keeper.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: These Keepers have been rumor'd to be churlish; I like this fellows humour very well.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh what a crew of Wine-Leaches shal we have stick upon us to morrow morning for our Garnish, we are of the Master-side, your half-crowns a piece Gentlemen, I know the order, I have commenc'd in this Colledge before now.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: A pottle of Canary in the Compter, score.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: In the Compter you rogue; Sir can't you shew us a better room.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: It is too late Sir, pray be civill, and keep your own room.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Is this the end of our travail? Here's a Health to our good deliverance.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: By the blood of Bacchus I'le pledge thee.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Come I'le begin a mad Health, and let every man have his fancie.
sp.l: Here's a curse to all those
That are Pris'ners foes,
And the Coward that goes
To undoe men for blows,
Who doth basely expose
Their bodies to throwes,
In a Prison where growes
Infection to th' nose,
And from top to the toes
Are tormented with woes,
Till, be it spoke under the Rose,
They'r meat for the Crowes,
Confusion to those
In Meeter and Prose.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Pray drink off your cup, and we'l all keep the close, here comes my white Knight in his Lawn sleeves, now if a Quaker saw him he would take his shirt for a Surpless, and condemn it for a Babylonish Garment, or in good sooth and verily a wicked and superstitious remnant of that foul flaps the whore of Babylon.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Begar dat whore of Babylon be one of me Aunts.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Monsieur you see we are come to bear you company, you shall not engross the prison to your self.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Me tank you for noting, you can no give me de sheat now as you have froÌ„ (vat do you cal de fader of de pig)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: The father of the Pig; a Hog.

sp.speaker: Sir R
sp.l: Hog, hog, hog, as you gave me de sheat at Hogdown.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Wel forget it, there was no hurt meant, on my credit, there was another cause you must not know.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: Begar but me do know already, you carry away de Surzhons vife, begar he be horn-mad.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: How came you to know this? would he reveal it?

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: Yes begar and more to, 'twas he dat make Drowzy de Kishin-wensh to arrest Monsieur Flylove.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: The devil at last is even with us.
sp.stage: Within. Room for my Lord Judge.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: How now what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: This noise is ith' Kings Ward; 'tis term'd the Hole.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: But are they allow'd to be so lowd there.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: We cannot check a Custome they have us'd,
Which is when a new Prisoner first comes in,
They have a Scaene of mirth, where one is Judge,
And sits a tryal upon life and death.
