sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: May we not see them Sir.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I have no priviledge to open Wards at this late hour oth' night, left some combustion happen amongst the prisoners, which my strength will be too weak to pacifie.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: My life for yours no danger Sir.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Ye appear honest Gentlemen, and I'le trust ye.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Thank you Sir; come Monsieur wil you walk down.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: Zhentlem me vill vait on you to morrow, but me mus com to bed; but me have anoder plot in my head begar.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Wel Monsieur good night, take rest, and sleep secure.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.l: Awee Monsieur tres humble serviteur.

sp.stage: Enter as in the Hole Wildfire, Lord Lows-proof, Steward Rentfree Constable-Lazy, and Chamberlain-Iaylbird.

sp.speaker: Rent.
sp.l: What is your name my friend?

sp.speaker: Lows.
sp.p: You must tell the Steward your name, you will be the sooner entred a member of the Sheriffs-Basket, there is (my friend) a strange miracle in our living, we never want meat yet keep continual fast; and yet all that fast, you may see by our Clothes we are loose enough; we live in imitation of the Owls, we sleep ith' day time, and revel all the night: Some beds we have for Gentlemen of quality, as my self being the Lord, Steward Rentfree, Constable Lazy, and Chamberlain Iaylbird.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I was a Page to a Knight that was a prisoner in this house Sir Rev. Lamard, my name is Wildfire.

sp.speaker: Lows.
sp.l: Prethee stand farther off, thou wilt melt me else.

sp.speaker: Iayl.
sp.l: My Lord begins to hiss.

sp.speaker: Lows.
sp.p: Gentlemen of the Kings-Ward let us consult upon the business, 'tis for the good of the Hole, and of the whole House; let us for once be wiser and honester then e'r we have been, there may come much mischief by this Wildfire, if he stay long he will consume us, and every creeping thing about us, our beds being all straw is very combustible; the very blowing on's nose blows a bed up.

sp.speaker: Rent.
sp.l: There's a Bug upon your Honours doublet.

sp.speaker: Lows.
sp.p: Is there but one, give it Wildfire, he is fit for nothing but to receive my Moabites in reversion, they may live upon him like so many Salamanders; I will petition to morrow for the discharge of Wildfire, he shall not stay with us, we must have Wildfire put out, 'tis pity such a spark should be in the Compter.
sp.stage: Enter Keeper, Flylove, Rivers, Wildblood, Mrs. Trimw.
sp.p: Stand aside, here comes the Gentlemen Rats, it is most fit I give them the first salutation; Gentlemen you are most unhappily incountred.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I do most unfortunately thank you Sir, we come to see your Revels, are they ended? are you my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lazy.
sp.l: Yes Sir, he's my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen we make bold to visit you, and (to be the better welcome) we have brought with us each man a bottle of Canary; who's that knocks?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: 'Tis somebody at the Compter-gate, some more Rats I believe.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Bring them hither of what degree soever.

sp.speaker: Lazy.
sp.p: I, I, Hole 'um, Hole 'um'; Rat, tat tat, this is the City-Mous-trap; here do we lye at a sure ward, revel all night, and breath defiance to the Watch and the Constable; we have suffered under the terrour of Authority, and now we have got the Law in our own hands.

sp.speaker: Lowzy.
sp.l: A Rat, a Rat, a Rat.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: What are they, Citizens or Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Low.
sp.p: No, no, they are neither Citizens nor Gentlemen, and yet they are a company for Lords, they are musicall Rats, singing Rats, men that are come to keep time in the Compter; they are crowding in, therefore you that mean to express your activity, prepare and be in readiness, a man in prison may easily do his sink-a-pace.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: These are the Blades that were with us at Hogsdon; this was some precise Constable, some brother oth' Family, that sent the Musicians to prison, or else some joviall Humourist that had a mind the prisoners should be merry to night; well my Masters, since you are here, strike up couragiously, here be Gentlemen have a mind to discover their footing, you shall not lose your labour, I'le pay your Fees in the morning.

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.l: We thank you noble Mr. Flylove.

sp.speaker: Low.
sp.p: Gentlemen, throw of your bottomless pantoffles, and let's to't, here's Sack to cherrish us when we have finished.

sp.speaker: Wildb.
sp.p: Gentlemen, we thank you, when we'r at liberty, we'l send you something worth your estimation, in the mean time drink that.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I come, let's go, I do not like the fume of this close room; how fare you Mrs. Trimwel?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: Well Sir, but that the scent is somewhat noysome, the room above, from whence we came, is sweeter.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Come, we'l go up agen then.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I, I, let's go, god-night good friends.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We thank you Gentlemen, we'l drink your healths to morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: In the morning Musick we'l keep our words with you, but I shall talk with you for the trick you put upon me at Hogsdon.

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.p: It was no fault of ours indeed Mr. Rivers, we'l mak't appear to morrow.
sp.stage: Exeunt Rivers, Mrs. Trim. Wildblood and Flylove.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Well, well, good night.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Good night to you all Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lows.
sp.p: Come my Masters we that were Dancers will make an equal division of the Gentlemans bounty, here is ten shillings, and we are six on's.

sp.speaker: Ren.
sp.l: 12. d. a piece, & the rest in drink among the prisners

sp.speaker: Lows.
sp.p: I like the motion well my equal Steward, here is some Sack left, that we'l drink with the Musitians, and excuse their Garnish in the morning.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Lows.
sp.p: Let us consult farther in our with-drawing room: How now Chamberlain cannot you leave your old trade? must you be filching? wouldst thou undo a poor Common-wealth at one pull thou unconscionable thief, but I am too subtil for you sirrah, you can't deceive me; The devil take me if my Angel leave me.

sp.speaker: Rent.
sp.l: Nobly spoke my Lord; room for my Lord there.
sp.stage: Enter above with a long rope Sir Rev. Lamard.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: 'Tis very light, begar me sall be discover; now if my string do slip, down goes Sir Reverence upon some Washmans head, and begar dat vill bewray all; I can see no candle, dere be no body up in de street, and me can hear noting but de Fiddles in de Prison; if I sall break my neck in sundra for my liberty, begar my adversary make dice of my bones, but I sall couzen him, for my bone crumble to ashes: So, so, vas very fast, and so fast, as me can, me vill down; Begar me tink it be somewhat strange dat me mus come to be save by de Rope, but if I be taken, for ought I know I sall be hang in de Rope. I care not me sall He slides down and resteth on the Feathers Tavern. ventre for all dat, as good be hang as live in prison: Begar here comes sombody vith light, me sall be taken, dere Ent. Pimpw. drunk with a Torch in his hand. be no vay to scape, and me canot clime up agen: Oh Diabolo vat sall become of me, de vindow be shut, me can no creep into de Tavern, and I sall not be taken for Zhorge a hors-back, as me saw once in de Play; begar dis man be drunk, I see by his stagger.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p:
A sawcy Constable to question my lodging, cannot a man go home to his house in peace? Is it not sufficient that I can carry my self to the Compter, but I must be beholding to an enigmatical Constable, and his mischievous
Watch; a man can no sooner come neer them, but who goes there? come before the Constable; Come afore a Cuckold, Oh such a rogue would be hang'd; Let me see, where am I? this is Woodstreet, whereabouts is the Feathers-Tavern.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: A pox for you, you be too neer de Feder-Tavern already, and begar now I see him, dis fellow be prisoner in de Compter, but I have an invention he sall no spy me, begar me vill creep into dis Bush, and ven he be gone me sall go down courageo.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: This is the Compter where many a man lies with a heavy heart, I have been a prisoner this two or three years, yet I walk abroad at my leasure, and am as drunk as a devil for my pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar me have extream need to make vater, I sall pish my breesh, Oh Diabolo I sall be found, begar me can stay no longra, me sall burse.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: I will knock up this rogue Hugh at the Feathers; Hugh, Hugh, you rogue rise, my name's Pimpwel, you sleepy rogue rise and let me in, must I wait upon you with a pox to you. Nouns what's that?

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Begar now I be undon in a pissing vhile.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: You son of a Batchelor, do you throw your Pispots upon my head, if I could finde stones I'de break your windows, but since I cannot, I will even make bold to see fire of your Bush, then throw your water and spare not.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Oh Mordieu, me sall be burn in de Bush, or be hang in de Rope, I vould I were in me shamber agen.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: What's here, a Rope? some prisoner Pimpw. spieth the rope. has made an escape out of the Mastersside; there's money for somebody to pay, I'le in and call the Turn-key, a prisoner escap't, a prisoner, a prisoner.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.l: A private chamber in the Masters-side.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.l: Look, look, here's the Rope.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Run up to the Masters side, see if the French Knight be in's Chamber, his Action is 6000. l. we are all undone if he escape away.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: I, I, we are all undone, if he be gone here's Rope enough for us all.

sp.speaker: 3. Keep.
sp.l: Pox on you for a drunken rogue, wher hast bin?

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: Drinking wine in bowls boys, I am almost drunk, but what shal we do for the prisoner, shall I run after him?

sp.speaker: 3. Keep.
sp.l: Which way is he gone?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: The Lord knows.

sp.speaker: 2. Keep.
sp.l: Hallowgh?

sp.speaker: 1. Keep.
sp.l: What say you?

sp.speaker: 2. Keep.
sp.p: The French Knight is escaped, you must make swift pursuit, he cannot be gone far.

sp.speaker: 1. Keep.
sp.p: Pluck up the Rope; look well toth' Gate, Pimpwel run you to Cripplegate, you to some other Watches, and all the way you run, cry out a prisoner.

sp.speaker: 3. Keep.
sp.l: A prisoner, a prisoner.
sp.stage: Sir Reverence comes out of the Bush.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Oh the great pox run with you all, vat a fear have dey put me in, begar me vill not stay, 'tis very light, I see no passenger, dis vas de bravest time: So, now me are down, futra for Keeper; begar me can no shuse but laugh, how dey run away from me to find me; Oh me brave bush! Fish vay sall me take to be safe, me mus come no neer Cripplegate, nor Sheapside, I sall take some udder vay, the devil is in me if I come agen; Farewell good Compter, I am not loath to part from you: I remember two line of an Englishman dat vent from de Prison, dey var des:
sp.l: Dis House mus be let at a miserable rate,
For I ha' lost my Shambra, any man may ha't:
Farewel Comptera.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: Can you direct me to the hapless lodging of yong

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: He lies ith' Masters-side, he is a Gentleman whose misery works much compassion in each Officer, I would my power could save him.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: Thank you Sir?
Such worthy wishes in such men as you,
Who bear a function of that cruel nature,
Being so rare, appears most excellent;
Pray tell me Sir, how doth he take his sufferings?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: I think he is in love; he's often heard
To sigh a Ladies name, and sing sad Sonnets
In dissolving passion,
Such as might melt the Tyger-cruelty
Of men turn'd Tyrants; thus much I observe,
The prison doth not fright him from his rest,
Like his divorce from her whose name he fighs so;
I'le call him if you please, yet 'tis somewhat early.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: Sir, I give thanks
Unto your loving diligence, and with your leave,
I shall conceive it but a friendly Office,
To spare his labour, and walk up to him.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Those stayrs direct you, turn on your left hand.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Are you the Keeper Sir?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: I turn the key, my Office is as much
To let men out as in; I take no pride,
To stand 'twixt men and freedome, suck a Keeper
I am, and would be thought.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Heaven be thy Keeper, and grant thy place corrupt thee not; pray Sir, was there not brought in amongst other Gentlemen, a prisoner late last night, call'd Mr. Flylove?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Yes Lady.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: How could I speak a word in private with him? the business which I have concerns his freedome.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: I shall be glad to call him,â€”Mr. Flylove.
sp.stage: Prisoners within. Mr. Flylove, Mr. Flylove. Ent. Flylove.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: What a noise you make, I'm become a man of calling now; who is't would speak with me Sir.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Here's a fair Lady, I'le leave you to your opportunity.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Gramercy honest Keeper: How now, who's this?
How my blood startles in me on the sudden?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: What, do I fright you Sir? I come to see and comfort you with my best love to file your Fetters off.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Such charitable language, and such face
Had beauteous Bellaflora, to whose soul
Mine was contracted, but my breach of vow,
Joyn'd with the infamy of this Ioath'd action,
So lately done, hath sent her far from me;
This is the pleasant widdow we met at Hogsdon,
I remember now;
But see how guilt will fool a man, I was
Admiring how you thought to finde me here.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Some other time I'le tell you, if I may
(Without the breach of modest manners) ask you
What is the cause of your imprisonment?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: What a question's that? I'le lye ith' Compter all my life time, e're I make known the cause that laid me here, a toy, a trifle, for nothing but disputing with the Constable, here's Iack Wildblood and Frank Rivers in the house (three merry boys be we) here's the woman too, will you go see them.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: No Sir, but if the cause of your restraint from freedom be of that easie value, you'l be gone within an hour.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I, I, within this hour at the farthest.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Poor man, how thou deceiv'st me and thy self,
I as much blush to let him understand
I know the cause of his affliction,
As he doth to reveal it; if you please
I'le stay till you go off.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: You may stay this twelve-month for ought aside I know; I must put her off, to say the plain truth Lady I have an Action entred against me since I came in.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: You need not let that fright you, I have so much skill, although a very unexperienc'd woman to tell you, whilst you are under the command of any Justice for the breach oth' peace, you are not lyable to any Action.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: She says true, where the Devil got you so much law?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Come, come, I know the cause that keeps you here.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: How! I am sorry for that.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I'st not a womans Action?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: A womans Action.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I have hit the mark, and I could name the party.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Lady I'le take my leave, I'm call'd above.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Indeed you are not Sir, pray stay a little,
I know you think the fact you have committed,
To be of that vile nature, that you blush
To tell or think I know it; you the less
Stand in my condemnation for the ill,
Because 'twas acted on so much deformity,
It makes me think some Witchcraft, drink, or madness
Possest you at that time; they being remov'd,
Your penitence brings back your ravisht worth,
And you are man agen, but the nice winner
Of every fair one's a judicious sinner,
And in that judgement multiplies each fact,
And findes his Tragedy in the last Act.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: This circumstance confirms your knowledge of it,
And I am sorry.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: That I know't.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Tis true.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: But if you please't shan't be the worse for you,
Would I were beautiful enough to please you,
Or had a mind that you might think so fair,
To merit your best wishes in the bliss
Of sacred Wedlock, you should then be sure
To shake this bondage off.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Pray let me pause.
My former rashness may take license for't;
I am in prison, and the Law exacts
My body for a year; I could produce
Such bayl as is sufficient for my freedom,
But I will perish e'r I reveal my scandall;
This woman's fair, and hath a face so like
To one, whose memory I owe my being,
I know not what to answer; Then agen
'Tis for my freedom, from a bondage which
May ruine soul and body; I'm resolv'd,
If Bellaflora knew it, so would she,
And pardon all, which works my Liberty.
You do not ask me this to try me, do you?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: No by those joys I wish for.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Nor tell me of my fact, or of your friendship,
At every angry occasion,
Which the best married pair seldome avoid.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: May all my life be made of discontents,
And they in old age kill me, if I do.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: How neer she comes to Bellaflora still,
In all her noble actions; If I could
Believe the Pythagorean axioms true,
Of transmigrated spirits, did the Grave
Contain my Bellaflora, I should think
This frame contain'd her soul, the Gods would sure
Consume me, if this Contract I now make
And seal, this vertuous woman were not lawful:
By all the joys eternal, by the hopes
I have to live a life that's long and blest,
To see a numerous issue fairly bred
In all their actions, sh â€¢ wing still the minds
Of their long sleeping Ancestors, I'le bee
Thy husband, love, and life, I'le marry thee.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: This day.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: This very day.
sp.stage: Within. Stephen Flylove, the Constable's come.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Sir, the Constable waits for you.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Delay not, ith' mean time I'le bayle you here,
Remember Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I doe.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Adieu my dear.

sp.stage: Enter Flyl. Bellafl. Rivers, Mrs. Trimwel and Wildblood.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: W â€¢ lcome to liberty my Cavaliers,
The gawdy portalls of the red-cheekt morn,
Stand wide to entertain you, and delight
Your sickned sences with the bright display
Of glittering Phoebus.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Your genius soars too high, you'l melt his wings.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I am aiery as Philetus when he tripp'd
Over the ears of Corn, and ne'r bent head;
I could out-run Atlanta.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Atlanta? within these two hours a Cripple could out-run thee, and give thee five in the fifteen:
sp.l: But Stephen, why so stupid? rowse thy spirit;
Can Liberty discomfort, or the exchange
Of grates for fragrant fields dismay thee thus.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Faith I am dull, and I ha' reason for't.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: What is the melancholly matter prethee?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: That which will move you all when I shall speak;
Mercurio's dead.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: He was well last night.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: He dy'd this morning.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Oh my poor lost friend!

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: His cruel Creditor is paid; Oh my Mercurio!

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I knew 'twould dull you all as well as I,
This day his Funeral is, I hope you'l be
The sad spectators of his Obsequies,
Raynard the Keeper will instruct you when,
And tell you more, pray go and leave me here,
I have a sadness that concerns not you,
I'le put it off and meet ye.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Good morrow Stephen.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Farewel friend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: Good morrow Mr. Flyl.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Your humble servant; Lady what stay you for?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Where would you have me be?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Where you please; I can't command your being.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: What means my Love?
Your speech betrays some discontent in you.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Yes, I'm troubled, Oh my sweet Bellaflora!

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Who do you sigh for Sir?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: A friend, a friend, an honest friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: This is a time to banish discontents.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: No, no, to increase them.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: It is an hour was made to consecrate our holy contract

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Why I, I told you so.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Will you not marry me.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I will not break my faith to Bellafl â€¢ ra
To gain a Queen, a Goddess.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Then you have plighted faith unto another.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Yes cunning temptress I have.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Why do you blemish my well-meaning heart,
With such a title?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Could your securer subtilty presume
On no deceit but this? Had you propos'd
Out of some Magazine of rarities,
Gold, Silver, Jewels, though they were as precious
As Erephile's Bracelet (which she sold
Her dear affecting husband for) I had
Esteem'd them all as nothing, but weak I
Too fond of (what I now curse) Liberty,
Must sell my peace, my life, and much I fear
My bliss eternal.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Oh you Angels, where
Lives there a faithful man, why did you make
This solemn Contract to me.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: 'Twas a bad protestation, and the breach
Is better then performance, yet because
You shall not say I cheated favours from you,
Resign me to my prison, where I'le live,
Onely with thinking of my Bellaflora,
Her very name shall purifie the ayre,
And make a dungeon grow as fragrant,
As Meadow Flowers in triumphant Iune.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Thou common man that dost two contracts break,
I have so much to say, I cannot speak.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Like men for Robberies that lose their breath,
I leave the prison to embrace my death.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: You are very wanton Frank.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Now I have got thee single, shall we try
An amorous duell for a boy now, I'm all fire,
And could perform an act 'bove Hercules;
Glue thy red lips to mine, and let us prove,
The jocund pleasure of the billing Dove.
Agen, once more, you do not do it heartily,
We'l make a numeration from a kiss,
Shall pose Arithmatick.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: You'l tell of this.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Steal, and reveal; he's a bold thief indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: There are too many such.
They cannot have a favour,â€”such a one.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: I, such a one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: As you imagine, but they must reveal it,
As if it were a second sport to tell it.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: They glory in their actions, and would prove
How much they merit by their Ladies love;
This I disdain.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: Do ye use to talk in your sleep, you'l tell it to your bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: You are too jealous of me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: Come then, I'le try thee, kiss me,
That's the first peal to bed, but I won't trust ye.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Why do you mock me thus?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: The cause being so great, I may be doubtful,
You'l have another Love, then out goes all,
But use your will.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: To do thy will a pleasure, shall we be private.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: As private as you please.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Such privacie best pleaseth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: Come let's away then.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Stay (upon better thought) I have
No such desire to't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Prethee be not angry, I am very loath to go to hell so easily.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: What pretty change is this?

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: I would it pleas'd you, pray satisfie one thought and I am for you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: Willingly.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: And truly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: By my life I will.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Did never silken Gallant with queint words,
A fair proportion'd body, and smooth chin,
Such as you women like, tempt you to this,
This feat, before I mov'd you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Never, prethee bethink thy self, you doubt me still.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: But you suspect me more, I vow never.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: How fain would I believe thee, if thou swear'st true,
Thou'rt fitter far for Heaven then this act,
Which thou shalt ne'r be guilty of for me;
What pitty 'tis to take fair new blancht Lawn,
And sprinkle ink on't; let not your husbands doubts,
Bred by your frequent absence, and such howers
Civility ne'r warranted, urge you
To acts that cause his shame, and your own shame.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: Whats' your intent for this.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: I'le tel you.
The guilty giddy people, who conceive
All acts more vile then they appear,
Have spred an infamy upon us both,
Which if unquell'd, in time will fix a stain,
(though causless) which no Rethorick can charm
To alteration; thus in brief I'le do,
By a most queint invention I have thought,
I shall return you to your husband, who
Shall with his love, not jealousie, embrace you,
And to the bold ears of the rumorous world,
Declare his errour, and your innocence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: A very modest way to do me mischief,
I thank you for your love, your honest love.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: That you'l confess hereafter, will you go?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: Yes Sir, I'le wait on you;
Am I betray'd by tricks? a Letter op'd,
The secret read, and then seal'd up agen?
Inquisitive fool, thy dear experience shall
Instruct thee, what a fate he undergoes,
That turns the fierce stream of a womans love:
I could be less impatient had he spoke
From knowledge of my guilt, then know my will,
And afterwards disclose me; well I'le disguise my anger,
And frame a fierce revenge shall make thee tremble,
Women act mischief sure when they dissemble.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Is the French Knight in prison, what is his debt?

sp.speaker: Splen.
sp.l: Six thousand pound they say Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Tis a great sum, I have been wrong enform'd,
'Twas credibly reported on the Change,
He had a free estate, his Traffick great,
A most unquestion'd credit; and doth all
Conclude in this, they did not mean me well
That tempted my belief thus.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: Shall my suit have gracious hearing yet Sir?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: What for Mereurio?
Because I was so neer to be deceiv'd,
With the feign'd riches of a Bankerupt,
Would you betray your self to certain beggery.

sp.speaker: Splen.
sp.l: Will you be pleas'd to free him from his bondage?
It is reported he is sick, that place
Will kill him, where is then your satisfaction?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: He cannot want a friend for twenty pound,
I will not lose my money, I'le take time,
If he can fit me with security.

sp.speaker: Splen.
sp.l: Alas he is not able.
sp.stage: Enter Mercurio on a Hearse, four Bearers (as Mourners) Wild. Riv. Flyl. Mrs. Trim. Raynard, Pimpwel. They set the Coffin before Nice, and Flylove makes an Oration.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: What are these; heark you friend, whose body's this?
And whither carry you it?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Here Sir our journey ends,
It is the body of deceas'd Mercurio,
A prisoner at your suit, who dyed this morning,
And thus according to an ancient custome,
We bear him to you (all that's left)
His bones to make you satisfaction,
Because his poverty enforc'd him (living)
To keep your right from you; withall, our form
Is to deliver to the Creditor,
At whose peculiar suit the debtor dyes,â€”A bale of Dice.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Strange custom; Heaven! how it doth amaze me.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I have a little speech that must excuse
The expences of a bought Oration, which concerns
His miserable end, and cause of it, and I have done.

sp.speaker: Splen.
sp.l: Oh my Mercurio.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Look to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: When he came in he wanted all that makes
Man in this Age substantial (Friends and Coyn)
Which want was soon attended with these, neglect & hunger
But then the perturbations of his minde,
His sighing silence onely could declare,
As if they were too vast for elocution;
Great griefs are tongue-ty'd, there's no clamour rear'd,
So deepest water crawl along unheard.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Most reverend piece of sorrow, whose wet eyes
Drop, as they would command another Spring,
To raise the body from its earthly ruine,
To heat and life agen; what friendship had you with him?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Sir, I am one,
That wish I had such neerness to his vertue,
As to his blood; a poor unhappy Kinsman.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: There's so much Magick in your sorrow Sir,
All my attentions charm'd.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Like men who are neer drowning, catch weak hold
On broken boords, on sedge, or any thing
Disastrous chance betrays to the wild waves,
He sends for me that could but grieve his sight,
With the wet sorrow in my eyes for him:
Instead of Chambers hung with Tapestry,
Arras, and Attick pictures, the dark walls
Are easly beautifi'd with Chalk and Cole,
According to the melancholly fancy
Of the sad Prisoners, where the numerous beds
Shew like so many Graves in a Churchyard,
With the men rising out: No Canopies
But what the charitable Spider wove,
To save their always watching eyes from danger,
For they'r un-us'd to sleep.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Alas poor men.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: In such a state as this my kinsman lay,
My poor, poor kinsman.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Thou weep'st too fast old man, I shal not overtake thee.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I sigh'd, sate down by him, and did observe
The manner of his Chamber mates, and one
Belov'd above the rest, as it appear'd,
Was cherisht with a friend that happy day,
Who said he came to see him, could not stay,
Although some Messenger six times had been
To fetch him, but in vain, was ne'r within
After he heard the business, though his eare
Was within hearing of the Messenger:
At last he was within, without all doubt,
Because he heard the prisoners going out,
Gives him a shilling, bids him have good cheer,
He was glad to see him, sorry to see him here,
And so he parts, protesting for to come,
He knows not when, this is his wretched doom
Of undone debtors, and my kinsmans Tomb.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Since bleeding cleanseth veins, I hope to finde
Th'expence of tears will purifie the minde:
What is this writing Sir?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: 'Tis his own hand,
One hour befor his death he writ his Epitaph.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: With his own hand? pray read it.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I shall Sir.

lg.head: EPITAPH.
lg.l: I which once with life did move,
Here lye Coffin'd up, to prove
Till death I was Splendora's Love.
I that have with many groans,
And wet eyes washt the prison stones,
For want of Money, pay my bones.
Let none with exclamation call,
Upon my name, and scorn my fall,
I ow'd but little, and paid all. Mercurio.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Thou hast paid all indeed, thy breath and all,
Is't were no sin I could bestow a wish,
That life would visit these cold corps agen.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Where shall we bury him Sir, the custome is
To bury men in debt ith' New-Churchyard;
Shall we dispose him there?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: No, since he's dead he shall be well interr'd,
Though half my estate waste for it, I have cause,
He lov'd Splendora, poor Girl she'l dye too;
To your charge I commit this forty pound,
sp.stage: Gives Rivers the Bag Exit Rivers.
sp.l: To provide mourning; I'le have Surgeons strait,
That shall embalm the body.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: You shew your self a noble Gentleman,
Whose memory we'l pray for; here Frank dispatch.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Sir, here be Gentlemen that lov'd him, are
Willing to express their loves, they have a Dirge.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: They are welcom, I'le attend their ceremony.

lg.head: The Dirge. They sing.
lg.l: FRom selling, or from mortgaging of Lands,
From turning over goods in others hands,
And from the setting of our marks to bands.
From cruelty that keeps good men in awe,
From Serjeants, and such Griffins of the Law,
And from the chattering of an Yeild-hall Daw.
From living at a miserable rate,
In prison where all people are ingrate,
And from the Porters at the Compter gate.
From being dragg'd in there with cruel gripes,
By an old cursed Catchpole called Tripes,
From paying for our Candles and our Pipes,
Next from the Stocks, the Hole, and Little-ease,
Sad places, which kind Nature do displease,
And from the ratling of the Keepers Keys,

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Is all perform'd?

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: To a tittle, here's a discharge from the Office.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Then rise from thy dead sleep thou man of care,
Thy debt is paid, there's joyful news for thee.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Am I deluded,

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Not a jot, come old man embrace him for your son,
Though he be poor, he is a Gentleman, and meritorious.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: But art thou living?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: I, you know it well enough, you shall even go together for your plots, I have paid my self it seems.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Your Money lies ith' Office Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: 'Tis very well, who comes here?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Ware ho! here comes a mad man.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Yes, a horn-mad man, Myruon are you there?
And your Sweetheart Rivers, I must part you;
Unhand him impudence. Rivers draws. [heart.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Sir, if you lay a violent hand on her, I touch your

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Gentlemen, Is there law or conscience in this?
To keep a mans wife, as they say, in spight on's teeth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: F. Rivers is more kind then I expected.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Your jealousie hath wrackt her vertuous name,
And by my life she's free from actual ill,
As e're thy mother was.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: He'l ne'r believe you.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: No, he shall I warrant you,
E're I commit her to your cursed usage,
I'l see some reformation of your life.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: You'l see't.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Yes Sir, I'le see't.
My Mothers daughter shall not be expos'd
Unto your giddy humors.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Your Mothers daughter?

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Yes Sir, my Sister.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: What trick is this?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Pray what may I call your name Sir.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: I never fear'd it, though I have disguis'd it,
For some ends which best concern my self,
Before I went to France, men that would know
By my own name to call me, call'd me Brooks.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: My brother Frederick?

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: The same Sister; I must talk with you.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Oh, my shame! Brother I hope you'l forgive me.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: This is no time nor place for our contention.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Who comes here?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Either my eyes deceive me, or here comes.
The form of Bellaflora.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: What do you gaze? Do you not know me Sir?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Yes sure, I know you; Are not you Bellaflora?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: That is my name.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I know it is, but were not you disguis'd, and call'd Fairchaste?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I remember your amorous Alphabet.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: O my strange excellent fortune; can you forgive all?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Yes, and seal my self thy own for ever.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: My dear Cousin.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Tis so indeed, the Wildblood's out, this is your cousin Worthlove.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Welcome from France good Cousin.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Fair cousin I thank thee, this unity contents me.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: As I live here's Sir R. Lamard that broke the prison, how the devil dares he venter.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Be your leave Zhentelmen, room for Sir Reveren. who be come to claim his Lady, his Madam.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: How came you out of prison Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar me pay de mony, and now me come to your dautera.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Now you have paid away your mony, the truth is,
Sir she is dispos'd of to another.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: And we'l dispose of you that can break prisons.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Begar here be de Keeper, vat fall me do now?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Nay, you'r fast enough, we'l take an order for your Ili-

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Zhentelmen vill no man be my bayl? [ding.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: The sum is too great for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Pray Zhentelmen.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Come Sir, you must to prison agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Mus, begar me vill not.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.l: Then we must force you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: You Pimping rogue, why do you tug me thus?
You know me well enough.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: What is your tongue chang'd, what tricks have you?

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: I'le speak with Mr. Nice. Pray Sir, peruse that Picture and Letter.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: 'Tis my wives picture sure; Splendora, was not this your Mothers picture?

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: Yes Sir, the very same she gave my brother, when he went to Paris.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: And this my hand, the Letter that I sent him.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: And I your son, come to crave a blessing.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: And with my heart thou hast it.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Will Nice.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Mr. Brooks your servant.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Noble Mr. Nice.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Hah, my politick Stephen.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: No, my politick William.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Sir I am yours, and joy to see you in England.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: Welcome to London brother, you can court a Lady most exactly in broken French.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: I am glad it pleas'd you sister; Keepers I'le quit you presently, that Action which was entred was a plot of mine, to have my father match this Gentleman with my kind sister; there's no danger in't I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Well, I'm contented Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: You are wags I see; were you sent seven years ago France, and come agen to cozen your friends, but Heaven be your joy. Come, cannot you express a little of your French action with these Ladies, shal we not have a Dance?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: And very fit, methinks the time requires it.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Every man take his Lady then.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Gentlemen, y'have done exceeding well; if you please to walk in, Dinner at this hour waits for you.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Come my mad merry Mates and fellow-Travellers, let's in and chat the story of our Travels, the tricks of our Disguises, with the queint and jovial Humours which we have found ith' Compter.
sp.l: To marry and be civill our next care is,
We now have done enough for Youths Fegaries.

lg.l: WEll; How is't now? we heard you laugh, but pray
Was it at us, the Poet, or the Play?
The Poet's full of joy though, to the brim,
And sayes, he's sure ye do not laugh at him;
Because, he findes you onely laugh at that,
Which he desires may be worth laughing at:
And then he heard you Clap; that Verdict stands
In Law, he hath it under all your hands;
Vnless when we were freed from Woodstreet Den,
You had a plot to Clap us up agen:
But waving all, we (without more suspence)
Accept your Clapping in the better sense.
This is the sum, I have no more to say,
Either for Poet, Actors, or the Play:
If his dull Humours please not, we implore,
That you'l go all toth' Compter and see more.

div.p: THis Comedy, called, The Walks of Islington and Hogsdon, With the Humours of Woodstreet-Compter, may be Acted: This 2. August, 1641.
